title: 1 Dr. Shaun stops an ongoing surgery
description: Dr. Murphy notices an anomaly during a procedure and decides to intervene. Learn key surgical vocabulary.

vocabulary.def: A medical operation or method of treatment
Something abnormal or irregular in a patient’s body
A cut made during surgery
An unexpected medical problem during or after surgery
Completely clean and free from bacteria
The presence of harmful substances or infection
The act of identifying a disease from its signs
To step in or take action to prevent harm
A set of rules or procedures to follow
A stitch used to close a wound

questions.question: General Understanding: Why does Dr. Shaun stop the surgery?

options.text: He notices an anomaly not seen on scans
He is tired and needs a break

questions.feedback: Correct. He saw something irregular that wasn't in the plan.

questions.question: How does the surgical team initially react to his interruption?

options.text: They ask him to leave the room

questions.feedback: Correct. Stopping mid-surgery breaks protocol, so they were shocked.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'This ___ isn’t what the scans showed — stop cutting!'
questions.feedback: Correct. Anomaly means something abnormal.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'We need to close the ___ immediately and reassess.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Incision is the surgical cut.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'If we continue, there’s a high risk of ___.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Unexpected actions lead to complications.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'Dr. Murphy, you can’t just ___ in the middle of an operation!'
questions.feedback: Correct. To intervene means to step in.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'There’s possible ___ of the surgical field.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Contamination means the area is no longer sterile.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'Keep the area ___, change gloves, new instruments.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Sterile means germ-free.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'Let’s double-check the patient’s ___; maybe we missed something.'
questions.feedback: Correct. They need to verify what disease they are treating.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'We’ll need to ___ and re-suture the area.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Suture means to stitch up.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'We must follow hospital ___ even if the situation changes.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Protocol is the set of rules.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'It’s rare to stop a ___ halfway, but Shaun made the right call.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Procedure refers to the medical operation.

questions.question: Post-Watching: Was Shaun right to stop the procedure?

options.text: No, he should have stayed quiet

questions.feedback: Correct. Patient safety always comes first.

questions.question: Definition Check: What is a 'suture'?

options.text: A stitch used to close a wound

questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: Definition Check: What does 'sterile' mean?

options.text: Completely clean and free from bacteria

questions.feedback: Correct.

title: 2 Sinus Infection Case
description: Dr. Shaun identifies a blocked sinus and performs a drainage procedure. Vocabulary: congestion, drainage, inflammation.

vocabulary.def: Transfer of an organ or tissue from one person to another
Person or body who gives something for use in another
A medical test removing tissue to examine it for disease
The removal or clearing out of waste or unwanted matter
Able to live or be used; capable of functioning
Something that increases the difficulty or risk
A pipe or channel used to carry fluid or other items
Sudden, sharp, severe condition
Material left over or fragments
The act of giving permission for a medical procedure

questions.question: The surgeon says: 'We need the donor liver to remain ___ so we can implant it successfully.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Viable means capable of functioning.

questions.question: The team discovers ___ in the vascular conduit that could cause graft failure.
questions.feedback: Correct. Debris refers to waste or fragments.

questions.question: The patient’s condition changed from chronic to ___, requiring immediate attention.
questions.feedback: Correct. Acute means sudden and severe.

questions.question: Before transferring the child, the parents sign ___ for the procedure.
questions.feedback: Correct. Consent is permission.

questions.question: A ___ of infection makes the transplant more complicated.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: They perform liver irrigation to flush out remaining blood and ___.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: The donor is flown in using a temporary ___ for transport.
questions.feedback: Correct. Conduit refers to the channel/method used.

questions.question: The tissue biopsy confirms the organ is free of disease and is ___ for transplant.
questions.feedback: Correct.

title: 3 Hidden Questions in Dr. Shaun's Mind
description: Dr. Shaun questions a diagnosis and faces an ethical dilemma. Vocabulary: assumption, probe, dilemma, strategist.

vocabulary.def: Continuing for a long time, often not wanted
Something accepted as true without proof
A meeting with an expert to seek advice
Very worried or nervous about something
To examine or explore something carefully
Real but not immediately obvious
A situation in which a difficult choice must be made
A person skilled in planning or managing a plan
The act of making something known or public
A particular attitude or way of thinking about something

questions.question: Dr. Shaun says: 'I keep having this ___ in the back of my mind.'
questions.feedback: Correct. He questions his initial assumption.

questions.question: The nurse suggests: 'You need to ___ the underlying cause.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Probe means to investigate deeply.

questions.question: Dr. Shaun noticed the patient seemed particularly ___ about the test results.
questions.feedback: Correct. Anxious means worried.

questions.question: Shaun mentions an ethical ___ about how much disclosure the patient should get.
questions.feedback: Correct. A dilemma is a difficult choice.

questions.question: Another doctor advises: 'You have to approach this like a ___.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Planning ahead like a strategist.

questions.question: What is the 'underlying cause'?

options.text: The real, hidden reason for the problem
The visible symptom on the skin

questions.feedback: Correct. Underlying means real but not obvious.

title: 4 Dr. Shaun explores some of the most unique medical mysteries of all time
description: Dr. Shaun explores rare cases that defy current paradigms. Vocabulary: anomaly, perplexing, interdisciplinary.

vocabulary.def: Something that deviates from the norm
Not clearly understood or easily seen
Relating to diagnosis or identifying a disease
Causing confusion or puzzlement
A typical example or pattern of something
A proposed explanation made on the basis of little evidence
A surprising and previously unknown fact discovered
Involving two or more academic disciplines
A visible or tangible example of something abstract
Difficult to find, catch, or achieve

questions.question: Dr. Shaun says: 'This case is not just rare; it’s an ___ that defies our current paradigm.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Anomaly means a deviation from the norm.

questions.question: Narrator: 'Her symptoms were so ___ that even the most experienced specialists were baffled.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Perplexing means confusing.

questions.question: Dr. Shaun: 'The manifestation of the disease is ___ rather than overt.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Obscure means not clearly seen.

questions.question: We formed an ___ team of cardiology, neurology and infectious-disease.
questions.feedback: Correct. A team involving multiple disciplines.

questions.question: Finally, a ___: the real culprit was a hidden virus.
questions.feedback: Correct. Revelation is a surprising fact discovered.

title: 5 Unique Medical Mysteries
description: Dr. Shaun explores rare cases that defy current paradigms. Vocabulary: anomaly, perplexing, interdisciplinary.

vocabulary.def: Something that deviates from the norm
Not clearly understood or easily seen
Relating to diagnosis or identifying a disease
Causing confusion or puzzlement
A typical example or pattern of something
A proposed explanation based on little evidence
A surprising and previously unknown fact discovered
Involving two or more academic disciplines
A visible or tangible example of something abstract
Difficult to find, catch, or achieve

questions.question: Dr. Shaun says: 'This case is not just rare; it’s an ___ that defies our current paradigm.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Anomaly means a deviation from the norm.

questions.question: Narrator: 'Her symptoms were so ___ that even the most experienced specialists were baffled.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Perplexing means confusing.

questions.question: Dr. Shaun: 'The manifestation of the disease is ___ rather than overt.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Obscure means not clearly seen.

questions.question: We formed an ___ team of cardiology, neurology and infectious-disease.
questions.feedback: Correct. A team involving multiple disciplines.

questions.question: Finally, a ___: the real culprit was a hidden virus.
questions.feedback: Correct. Revelation is a surprising fact discovered.

title: 6 Dr. Shaun Fails to Save a Baby
description: Dr. Murphy notices an anomaly during a procedure and decides to intervene. Learn key surgical vocabulary.

vocabulary.def: A medical operation or method of treatment
Something abnormal or irregular in a patient’s body
A cut made during surgery
An unexpected medical problem during or after surgery
Completely clean and free from bacteria
The presence of harmful substances or infection
The act of identifying a disease from its signs
To step in or take action to prevent harm
A set of rules or procedures to follow in medical settings
A stitch used to close a wound

questions.question: General Understanding: Why does Dr. Shaun stop the surgery?

options.text: He notices an anomaly not seen on scans
He is tired and needs a break

questions.feedback: Correct. He saw something irregular that wasn't in the plan.

questions.question: How does the surgical team initially react to his interruption?

options.text: They ask him to leave the room

questions.feedback: Correct. Stopping mid-surgery breaks protocol, so they were shocked.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'This ___ isn’t what the scans showed — stop cutting!'
questions.feedback: Correct. Anomaly means something abnormal.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'We need to close the ___ immediately and reassess.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Incision is the surgical cut.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'If we continue, there’s a high risk of ___.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Unexpected actions lead to complications.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'Dr. Murphy, you can’t just ___ in the middle of an operation!'
questions.feedback: Correct. To intervene means to step in.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'There’s possible ___ of the surgical field.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Contamination means the area is no longer sterile.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'Keep the area ___, change gloves, new instruments.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Sterile means germ-free.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'Let’s double-check the patient’s ___; maybe we missed something.'
questions.feedback: Correct. They need to verify what disease they are treating.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'We’ll need to ___ and re-suture the area.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Suture means to stitch up.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'We must follow hospital ___ even if the situation changes.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Protocol is the set of rules.

questions.question: Gap Fill: 'It’s rare to stop a ___ halfway, but Shaun made the right call.'
questions.feedback: Correct. Procedure refers to the medical operation.

title: Excellent Medical Plan
description: A critical emergency involving a newborn baby. Focuses on medical vocabulary related to resuscitation and vital signs.

vocabulary.def: a newborn baby, especially one less than four weeks old
to revive someone from unconsciousness or apparent death
essential body signs such as heartbeat, breathing rate, temperature
the process of supplying or saturating the body with oxygen
a special heated bed used for premature babies
a hospital emergency indicating a patient in cardiac arrest
a machine that helps a patient breathe
emergency procedure combining chest compressions and artificial respiration
the regular movement of the heart as it sends blood around the body
a continuous line on a monitor showing no heart activity

questions.question: The final ___ confirms Shaun’s assumption was right.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: Shaun recommends a less ___ procedure.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “Prepare the ___ — we need to stabilize the infant’s temperature.”
questions.feedback: The incubator is used to stabilize the fragile infant's temperature.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “Check the baby’s ___ — heart rate and oxygen levels are dropping.”
questions.feedback: Heart rate and oxygen levels are essential body signs, or vitals.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “Start chest compressions! Begin ___ now!”
questions.feedback: Chest compressions are part of the CPR procedure.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “No response. Connect to the ___ for assisted breathing.”
questions.feedback: The ventilator is a machine that helps a patient breathe.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “Oxygen saturation is too low; ___ is failing.”
questions.feedback: Oxygenation is the process of supplying the body with oxygen.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “This is a ___ situation — call the emergency team!”
questions.feedback: A 'code blue' indicates a hospital emergency, usually cardiac arrest.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “We’ve lost the ___, there’s no pulse detected.”
questions.feedback: The heartbeat is the regular movement of the heart, which is checked for a pulse.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “Continue trying to ___ the baby — don’t stop compressions yet!”
questions.feedback: To resuscitate means to revive someone from apparent death.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “I’m sorry… it’s a ___.”
questions.feedback: A flatline shows no heart activity, indicating death.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: “The ___ is too weak, we’re losing temperature fast.”
questions.feedback: The neonate (newborn baby) is the patient who is weak and losing temperature.

title: Big Medical Mission
description: Developing a precise and patient-safe treatment plan, often involving disagreement among doctors. Vocabulary: diagnosis, recommend, precise, procedure.

vocabulary.def: A careful judgment made after examining symptoms
A detailed suggestion for patient treatment
To suggest or advise a medical procedure
A discussion between doctor and patient before treatment
A specific type of medical operation or intervention
Accurate and exact
Difficulties or negative outcomes during/after a procedure
To assess or judge the condition of something
Relating to surgery or operations
The process of getting better after an illness or operation

questions.question: Shaun establishes a ___ area to sort patients.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: Nurses worked to ___ the patient’s vital signs.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: Shaun ___ a less invasive procedure to reduce the risk.
questions.feedback: To recommend is to suggest or advise a course of action[cite: 9].

questions.question: Fill in the gap: The final ___ confirms Shaun’s assumption was right.
questions.feedback: A diagnosis is a careful judgment made after examining symptoms[cite: 9].

questions.question: Fill in the gap: The team performs the surgery with ___ coordination.
questions.feedback: Precise means accurate and exact[cite: 38, 42].

questions.question: What is the synonym for the term 'recommend'?
questions.feedback: The synonym for recommend is suggest[cite: 42].

questions.question: What is the correct form: The correct ___ allowed the team to choose an appropriate treatment.
questions.feedback: The correct noun form for this context is diagnosis[cite: 56].

questions.question: What is the correct form: The doctors carefully ___ the patient’s condition before the operation.
questions.feedback: The correct verb form is evaluated (past tense of evaluate/assess)[cite: 57, 42].

questions.question: What is the correct form: Fortunately, there were no ___ during or after surgery.
questions.feedback: Complications are difficulties or negative outcomes[cite: 59, 42].

title: Repercussion of First Surgery
description: Shaun Murphy takes the lead on a medical mission in a field hospital after a disaster. Focuses on emergency procedures and working under limited conditions.

vocabulary.def: A humanitarian task aimed at helping others
A person offering help without payment
To perform an operation or medical procedure
A system for prioritizing patients based on medical urgency
A dangerous or difficult situation requiring quick medical response
Necessary tools and medical supplies
To keep the patient’s condition from worsening
The process of getting better after an illness or operation

questions.question: The patient developed a severe ___ during the operation.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: They used multiple ___ to control the bleeding.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: Shaun quickly establishes a ___ area to sort patients by injury level.
questions.feedback: Triage is the system for prioritizing patients based on urgency.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: The lack of proper ___ makes the operation more difficult.
questions.feedback: Lack of proper tools (equipment) complicates surgery.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: The team faces an unexpected ___ when the power fails.
questions.feedback: An unexpected problem is a complication.

questions.question: Synonyms: 'emergency care' means...
questions.feedback: Emergency care is equivalent to urgent treatment.

questions.question: The phrase “field conditions” means...
questions.feedback: Field conditions refer to an outdoor or temporary medical setup.

questions.question: “Stabilize the patient” means...

options.text: keep the patient’s condition from worsening

questions.feedback: To stabilize a patient means to prevent their condition from worsening.

questions.question: Word Form: Nurses worked to ___ the patient’s vital signs.
questions.feedback: The verb stabilize means to keep the condition from worsening.

questions.question: Word Form: Several patients were seriously ___ in the disaster.
questions.feedback: The correct past participle/adjective form is injured.

title: Complex Brain Surgery
description: Shaun performs his first independent surgical procedure which results in an unexpected complication. Focuses on surgical mistakes and accountability.

vocabulary.def: An unexpected medical problem after surgery
Stitch used to close a wound
Long-term consequence or aftereffect of an action
The cut made during an operation
To fix or correct a medical problem through surgery
Loss of blood from the circulatory system
To oversee or direct an operation
The result of treatment or surgery

questions.question: The surgery involves the ___.
questions.feedback: Correct.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: The patient developed a severe ___ during the operation.
questions.feedback: A complication is an unexpected medical problem during surgery.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: They used multiple ___ to control the bleeding.
questions.feedback: A suture is a stitch used to close a wound or stop bleeding.

questions.question: Fill in the gap: After the surgery, the team discussed possible ___.
questions.feedback: Repercussions are long-term consequences or aftereffects of an action.

questions.question: Which term means 'The cut made during an operation'?
questions.feedback: Incision is the term for the surgical cut.

questions.question: What does 'Post-op' refer to?
questions.feedback: Post-op is short for post-operation.

questions.question: A 'repercussion' is...
questions.feedback: A repercussion is a long-term result or consequence.

questions.question: Synonyms: 'surgical error' means...
questions.feedback: Surgical error is a synonym for medical mistake.

questions.question: Word Form: The patient started to ___ during the operation.
questions.feedback: The correct verb form is bleed (to lose blood).
